I don't see the problem. ![:dubbio:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/dubbio.gif)  

A USB hard disk - no matter if 1 Tb - can be partitioned (and the partition(s) formatted) "normally" by Disk Management of any recent NT bassed OS.  

Since you want to make it a multiboot "installing from" media, with - among other OS - Windows 7, most probably a suitable approach is the one of pre-booting to a windows PE 3.x:  
[http://www.msfn.org/...ndows-from-usb/](http://www.msfn.org/board/forum/157-install-windows-from-usb/ "External link")  
[http://www.msfn.org/...0-from-usb-hdd/](http://www.msfn.org/board/topic/139654-install-windows-from-iso-after-booting-to-winpe-30-from-usb-hdd/ "External link")

I mean most of the problems with USB device is related to "USB sticks" that are flagged as "Removable" and thus need some special trick to be partitioned/formatted, a USB hard disk is seen as "Fixed" and thus you can use normal tools on it.  

Making a single 1 Tb HUGE partition is, as I see it, pure folly, and \*could\* create some problems when booitng, possibly due to BIOS limitations, but the size of the drive itself should not.  

Have you problems in partitioning/formatting/making bootable that hard disk or not? ![:unsure:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/unsure.png)

forumNotes.author: Chaos_Cubed
forumNotes.content:
I had a situation trying to get a 1TB USB drive to boot and after trying multiple times to format it and run through my processes, I found that the drive was not responding quickly enough for the bios to recognize that it was a bootable device and would move on to the next device. (If you have a spare PC, I highly reccomend setting the only boot device as USB so it doesn't bounce to the hard drive automatically.)  

I found that if I timed the powering on of the USB drive and the powering on of the computer just right, it would boot up just fine. If your method works for your USB stick, perhaps try again with the timing of powering on the USB drive and PC.  

Good luck!  

Chaos.

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
I'll try again. Most tutorials and programs have been developed for USB sticks, you DO NOT need ANY of them for a hard disk. DO NOT use ANY other app but the standard Disk Management. DO NOT follow ANY other tutorial. You are just trying to make a USB hard disk bootable, at the moment. WHICH OS are you running? I mean either of: * 2K/XP/Server 2003 * Vista :dubbio:/Server 2008/7?
Create with Disk Management on the 1 TB hard disk one single partition, FAT16, around 1 Gb in size, make it Primary and Active. Format it under the OS you are running. Do NOTHING else. Try booting from the drive. What happens? You should normally see an error like "missing NTLDR" or "missing BOOTMGR". If you don't see the above, try changing settings in BIOS and try again, this oldish page (FAQ #10) may give you some ideas: [http://jaclaz.alterv...SB/USBfaqs.html](http://jaclaz.altervista.org/Projects/USB/USBfaqs.html "External link") Settings I would try at first sight: > USB Mass Storage Emulation Type: > (1)Auto > (2)Removable Disk > **(3)Fixed Disk** > (4)Size > Default chosen is: Auto. > Another option Boot USB order. Now chosen Hardisk, next CDROM This is strange, it doesn't look like the Intel guide: [http://download.inte...ybymenu_v13.pdf](http://download.intel.com/support/motherboards/desktop/sb/biosglossarybymenu_v13.pdf "External link") You should have something like "USB" or "USB first". > Another option USB legacy: Enabled This may create a conflict, for experimenting you may try disabling it, though I don't think it's anymore the case (it used to be on very old motherboards) ![:unsure:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/unsure.png) Wonko P.S.: A timing problem as **Chaos_Cubed** pointed out is quite possible, the drive should be powered ON before booting the PC or you may want to boot the PC, enter the BIOS, do something in it and exit it (this should allow for the timeing) or you could (if you have this option available) try booting using the Fn key usually F12 that allows to change boot order.

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
Good. ![:unsure:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/unsure.png) Now the BIG problem. Some (but not all disks) will start spinning when powered up. Some will "wait" some kind of acknowledge on the USB bus. If the drive is of the second type you are pretty much stuck. ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) As said sometimes using the F12 boot option is enough to delay the booting, but it seems like it is not working for you. Check the specific manual for that board ***maybe*** there is some more "advanced" setting in BIOS to take care of the problem ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) Some disks/controllers ***may*** be re-programmed to spin-up earlier, but you would have to check the actual drive and controller, possibly needing to open the case, thus voiding warranty. Don't do it! You can try using PLoP as a bootloader on the internal hard disk. ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) Theory of operation (assuming you boot normally XP on the HD now): * boot from internal hard disk * choose PLoP in BOOT.INI * choose to boot from USB
Here: [http://www.plop.at/en/bootmanager.html](http://www.plop.at/en/bootmanager.html "External link") [http://www.msfn.org/...howtopic=140412](http://www.msfn.org/board/index.php?showtopic=140412 "External link") ![:dubbio:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/dubbio.gif) Wonko P.S.: (and slightly OT) the 880 Gb partition is IMHO a bit "biggish" still. It means that if for any reason you have to image a partition for data recovery, it will fit ONLY on another 1 Tb drive. Making two of 440 Gb would allow using 500 Gb drives which are more common.

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
The general idea is to NOT install it at all. Rather chainload it from your existing BOOT.INI. > Theory of operation (assuming you boot normally XP on the HD now): > > * boot from internal hard disk > * choose PLoP in BOOT.INI > * choose to boot from USB > >
>
See here: [http://www.plop.at/e....html#noinstall](http://www.plop.at/en/bootmanager.html#noinstall "External link") > Run from the Windows boot menu (2K, XP, VISTA and Win7) It's simple, if you choose the PLoP entry in BOOT.INI it will load, if you don't it will not, no change is made to MBR or bootsector you just have an additional file on your first partition. You can also configure PLoP with plpcfgbt to boot hidden and default to USB: [http://www.plop.at/e...r.html#plpcfgbt](http://www.plop.at/en/bootmanager.html#plpcfgbt "External link") > Configure hidden boot and boot the usb device > > ``` > plpcfgbt stm=hidden cnt=on cntval=1 dbt=usb plpbt.bin > ``` > >
>
![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) Wonko

The hard drive I had timing problems was thankfully an externally powered device and thus, I was able to power it on before powering on the PC.   

Since the WD MY Passport is a USB powered drive, would it be possible to use a powered USB hub to provide power to the drive before you power on the PC?  

Also, instead of removing your internal hard drive, you should be able to go into your BIOS boot options and exclude your internal hard drive from the boot order while testing. You might be able to add an option for the internal hard drive from your boot.ini menu. That should force it to use the external USB drive and allow you to boot the computer normally if desired.  

Chaos
